article_title: San Antonio started 2016 with strong job growth
article_text:
San Antonio started 2016 with strong job growth

Photo: J. MICHAEL SHORT /SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS-NEWS Keith Phillips, an economist with San Antonio branch of the Federal...

The San Antonio area saw a surprise annualized job growth rate of 6.6 percent in January, by far the best rate in Texas, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas.

article_metadata.description: “One-month data can get pretty jumpy,” said Keith Phillips, assistant vice president and senior economist at the San Antonio branch office of the Dallas Fed.  Phillips has said an increase in the number of people with health insurance, because of the Affordable Care Act, is boosting healthcare hiring.  Statewide, the Federal Reserve Bank sees weakness from the strong U.S. dollar exchange rates, which slows export sales, and in low energy prices, which are causing layoffs at energy companies.  Job growth remains strong along the Interstate 35 corridor of Dallas, Austin and San Antonio.  Since January, Phillips has predicted Texas job growth in 2016 will fall between 0.5 and 1.5 percent, depending on oil prices.
article_metadata.author.name: By David Hendricks, Staff Writer
